properties.Name: InventoryTransactionType
properties.Description:
A classification of Inventory Transactions based upon common functions performed.

Ex:
- Completion
- Consolidation
- Destroy
- Emergency Purchase
- Impound
- Incoming Inspection Hold
- In-Process Inspection Hold
- Inspection
- Inventory Accuracy Hold
- Let Down
- Miscellaneous Withdrawal
- Move
- Order Pack
- Quarantine
- Receiving Hold
- Reject
- Release
- Reorder
- Repackage
- Replenishment
- Reservation
- Return
- Return To Vendor
- Re-warehousing
- Rework
- Sampling
- Scrap
- Shelf Life Hold
- Store
- Transfer Order
- Withdrawal 

where:

COMPLETION
The release of a Unit Load from a production group for transportation to another material handling group or to storage.
 
CONSOLIDATION
The combining of material or Items from multiple partially filled storage locations into a single storage location to make space available for new Items.
 
DESTROY
Inventory that is destroyed because it is obsolete, defective or damaged.
 
EMERGENCY PURCHASE
 A purchase made when unpredictable needs must be met. This type of purchase is most often made when health, safety or conservation risks are imminent or when other imperative needs arise.
 
EMERGENCY REPLENISHMENT
Emergency replenishments occur when the stock drops to zero. They are normally built automatically into the inventory system as part of the allocation of orders.
 
IMPOUND
To place Items on hold - to prevent items from being used or shipped.
 
INCOMING INSPECTION HOLD
A hold designed to restrict the use of items until the inspection department has tested and approved them.
 
IN-PROCESS INSPECTION HOLD
A specialization hold designed to restrict the use of material until it can be inspected or until existing doubt about its quality can be addressed.
 
INSPECTION
The function responsible for measuring the quality of items and determining whether or not the item specifications have been met.
 
INVENTORY ACCURACY HOLD
A hold designed to restrict the use of material or items until the actual quantity on hand can be determined and corrections to the records made.
 
LET DOWN
Handling a unitized load from its position in the stack or storage rack down to a location where partial withdrawals can be made.
 
MISCELLANEOUS WITHDRAWAL
The withdrawal of small quantities of an Item, typically on short notice for internal company use.

These are charged to an internal account and may or may not be billed.

Miscellaneous moves are usually performed by a supervisor and it is them converted into a transaction by the material handler.
 
MOVE
The movement of inventory from one location to another within an inventory facility.

Movements are normally made under the control of the inventory system.
 
QUARANTINE
A transaction involving on-hand stock which has been segregated and is not available to meet customer requirements.
 
RECEIVING HOLD
A hold designed to restrict the use of material until the shipment in which it was received can be completely reconciled.
 
REJECT
Item(s) that are of doubtful or poor quality.
 
RELEASE
Removing a hold or restriction upon Items at a particular Inventory Location.
 
REORDER
An order for the replenishment of inventory.
 
REPACKAGE
The removal of inventory from one package and the placement of it into another.
 
REPLENISHMENT
The movement of material from reserve to forward picking to resupply the forward picking locations.

Replenishment is defined based on a comparison of the available inventory in the forward picking area with a replenishment point.

Regular replenishments are normally run once or several times each day.

Regular replenishments are usually triggered when the stock in a forward picking area drops below an established replenishment point.
 
RESERVATION
The reservation of an Item for a specific use.
 
RETURN
The return of Item to Inventory after having been picked or allocated in a similar manner.
 
RETURN TO VENDOR
Inventory that is returned to the Vendor because it is obsolete or unacceptable.
 
REWAREHOUSING
The practice of rehandling lots already in storage in order to make room or consolidate lots. Re-warehousing is a continuous process that involves handling due to the manner in which withdrawals are made from lots. Re-warehousing also occurs in making letdowns from the upper rack tiers or stacks to facilitate making withdrawals. One of the major hidden costs in re-warehousing.
 
REWORK
The process of correcting defects in Items or material.

Items that are to be re-worked and then returned to inventory.

Manufacturing reworks typically override holds and allow the Items to be returned to the Manufacturer Facility.
 
SAMPLING
The selection of Items for testing from a group of similar items.
 
SCRAP
Items determined to be unusable and unreturnable to the vendor or unable to be reworked.

Scrap is still inventory and has some assigned value.

Scrap cannot be used in a normal way as similar items and ultimately is sold or thrown out.
 
SHELF LIFE HOLD
A hold designed to restrict the use of Items that have exceeded their shelf life.
 
STORE
The movement of Items into a storage location.
 
TRANSFER ORDER
An order for the shipment or transfer of Items from one inventory facility to another.
 
WITHDRAWAL
The withdrawal of an Item from an Inventory Location.

Columns.Name: InventoryTransactionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Inventory Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: InventoryTransactionTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of the Inventory Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: InventoryTransactionTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Inventory Transaction Type.
